I have been thinking about how to characterize conditionals categorically. Here is a formulation different (I think) than @Tobias Fritz's .

Let Θ\ThetaΘ be a category of the form

Fig1.jpg

in which objects are standard measurable spaces with the same sample space, and morphisms are identity maps from finer spaces to coarser ones.

Let P:Δ1→Θ\mathbf{P}: \Delta 1 \rightarrow \ThetaP:Δ1→Θ be a cone from the singleton set to Θ\ThetaΘ.

Fig2.jpg

Then there exists another category Θ∗\Theta^*Θ∗ with the same objects as Θ\ThetaΘ and morphisms pointing the other way, along with a contravariant cone P∗:Δ1→Θ∗\mathbf{P}^*: \Delta 1 \rightarrow \Theta^*P∗:Δ1→Θ∗ such that the following diagram commutes:

Fig3.jpg

where δ:Θ∗⇒Θ\delta: \Theta^* \Rightarrow \Thetaδ:Θ∗⇒Θ is the natural transformation in which, for all i≥0i \geq 0i≥0, δΩi:Ωi→Ωi\delta_{\Omega_i}: \Omega_i \rightarrow \Omega_iδΩi​​:Ωi​→Ωi​ is the identity map.

Fig4.1.jpg

I think that this universal property entirely characterizes conditionals.

Nice idea! I need to think about it a little more and need to go soon, but for now let me just comment that your terminology and notation is a bit non-standard, which may impede communication with other category theorists. Specifically:

  • There is no such thing as a contravariant cone. Isn't your P∗\mathbf{P}^*P∗ just a cone in the usual sense? (It's clearly not a cocone!)
  • You first say that Θ\ThetaΘ is a category, but then you use notation implying that Θ\ThetaΘ is a functor, since it's the codomain of a natural transformation.
  • Your δ\deltaδ does can't actually be a natural transformation, since it seems to go from a contravariant functor to a covariant one. For a natural transformation, the domain and codomain must be functors of the same type.
  • Most importantly, you give an equational condition for a bunch of morphisms and call it a "universal property". This is not what we mean by a universal property. A universal property is what you have when you characterize an object by saying how to map into it [or out of it] from any other object. For example, "Giving a map into a product A×BA \times BA×B amounts to giving a map into AAA and a map into BBB".

This is not to criticize the idea, which I think goes in the right direction. (More on that later.) It's normal that your parlance will be a bit non-standard at the beginning, especially if you haven't talked to category theorists much before. I'm trying to point it out early so that it won't perpetuate.

Now how about that definition of conditionals itself? Let me first try to formulate it in my own words, and then see whether this is indeed what you have in mind.

Let Meas\mathsf{Meas}Meas be the category of measurable spaces and measurable maps, and let Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch be the Kleisli category of the Giry monad on Meas\mathsf{Meas}Meas, so that its morphisms are Markov kernels between measurable spaces. Then we have a canonical functor Meas→Stoch\mathsf{Meas} \to \mathsf{Stoch}Meas→Stoch. It turns every measurable map into the corresponding (deterministic) Markov kernel. It's worth noting that this functor is not faithful.

Suppose that we have f:Ω1→Ω0f : \Omega_1 \to \Omega_0f:Ω1​→Ω0​ in Meas\mathsf{Meas}Meas. Denoting the singleton measurable space by 111, a morphism P0:1→Ω1\mathbf{P}_0 : 1 \to \Omega_1P0​:1→Ω1​ in Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch is exactly a probability measure, so that (Ω0,P0)(\Omega_0,\mathbf{P}_0)(Ω0​,P0​) is a probability space. The pushforward of this measure is the composite 1→P0Ω1→fΩ01 \stackrel{\mathbf{P}_0}{\to} \Omega_1 \stackrel{f}{\to} \Omega_01→P0​Ω1​→fΩ0​ in Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch. If we denote it by P1\mathbf{P}_1P1​, then we can consider both measures as the two components of a cone from 111 to the diagram Ω1→Ω0\Omega_1 \to \Omega_0Ω1​→Ω0​ in Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch.

Now a conditional is a section α:Ω0→Ω1\alpha : \Omega_0 \to \Omega_1α:Ω0​→Ω1​ of fff in Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch, which means that f∘α=idf \circ \alpha = \mathrm{id}f∘α=id, and in addition such that α∘P0=P1\alpha \circ \mathbf{P}_0 = \mathbf{P}_1α∘P0​=P1​. In other words, α\alphaα must be a section such that P\mathbf{P}P also forms a cone with respect to the diagram Ω0→αΩ1\Omega_0 \stackrel{\alpha}{\to} \Omega_1Ω0​→αΩ1​.

Finally, it's worth noting that in some situations, such as in the theory of stochastic processes, we have more than just two measurable spaces, but rather a whole diagram, like …→Ω2→Ω1→Ω0\ldots \to \Omega_2 \to \Omega_1 \to \Omega_0…→Ω2​→Ω1​→Ω0​. In this case, the definition of conditional can be generalized straightforwardly by using the formulation in terms of sections and cones.

Is this an accurate representation of what you have in mind?

Thank you for the considered response. That is indeed what I had in mind.

Θ\ThetaΘ, Θ∗\Theta^*Θ∗, and Δ1\Delta 1Δ1 are actually functors from N∪{∞}\mathbf{N} \cup \{\infty\}N∪{∞} into Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch; and P\mathbf{P}P is a natural transformation.

It seems to me that there should be such a thing as a "contravariant" natural transformation, from a functor to a contravariant functor. Then P∗\mathbf{P}^*P∗ and δ\deltaδ would be just such a thing.

Here is something interesting:

If Ω0\Omega_0Ω0​ and Ω1\Omega_1Ω1​ are objects in Stoch\mathsf{Stoch}Stoch and i:Ω1→Ω0i: \Omega_1 \rightarrow \Omega_0i:Ω1​→Ω0​ is the pushforward of the identity map, then Ω1\Omega_1Ω1​ must have the same sample space as Ω0\Omega_0Ω0​ and a finer σ\sigmaσ-algebra.

As you mentioned above, any measure P:1→Ω1\mathbf{P}: 1 \rightarrow \Omega_1P:1→Ω1​ can be turned into a cone:

Fig2.1.jpg

A conditional expectation K:Ω0→Ω1K: \Omega_0 \rightarrow \Omega_1K:Ω0​→Ω1​ then makes the following diagram commute:

Fig2.2.jpg

Where Δ\DeltaΔ is the pushforward of the copy map x↦(x,x)x \mapsto (x, x)x↦(x,x), and δ:Ω0→Ω0\delta: \Omega_0 \rightarrow \Omega_0δ:Ω0​→Ω0​ is the identity morphism.

The equality

(K⊗δ)∘Δ=Δ∘K(K \otimes \delta) \circ \Delta = \Delta \circ K(K⊗δ)∘Δ=Δ∘K

is the "conditional determinism" property of conditional expectations, and the equality

(K⊗δ)∘Δ∘P0=Δ∘P1(K \otimes \delta) \circ \Delta \circ \mathbf{P}_0 = \Delta \circ \mathbf{P}_1(K⊗δ)∘Δ∘P0​=Δ∘P1​

is the projection property.

You're very welcome! It would be nice if we had some others chime in as well.

Concerning natural transformation from a covariant functor to a contravariant one, and things like that the important thing is to explain what you mean for any terminology that isn't standard (not textbook material). So by contravariant natural transformation, I assume that you mean this, but it's still a bit of a guess.

I can't quite parse your second diagram. What is the map Δ:Ω1→Ω1⊗Ω0\Delta : \Omega_1 \to \Omega_1 \otimes \Omega_0Δ:Ω1​→Ω1​⊗Ω0​?

What you have in mind may be this diagram? While this not a commutative diagram because the pentagon does not commute, it is a partially commutative diagram in the sense that it does commute when you start at Δ1\Delta 1Δ1. And this is precisely the definition of conditioning (in the form of Bayesian inversion) given by Cho and Jacobs, as in their (5) on p.10. (They write σ\sigmaσ instead of P\mathbf{P}P and ccc instead of iii and ddd instead of KKK.)

(One more silly terminology thing: I'm pretty sure that you don't intend KKK to be the conditional expectation, since that would be a map from functions on one space to functions on the other. What you seem to be referring to is called a regular conditional probability.)
